newsitem.title: ITALY: ALPINE SKIING-KOSTNER COMPLETES ITALY'S HAT-TRICK.
newsitem.headline: ALPINE SKIING-KOSTNER COMPLETES ITALY'S HAT-TRICK.

text.p: Isolde Kostner emulated compatriot Deborah Compagnoni and continued Italy's sweep of the women's gold medals at the Alpine skiing world championships on Tuesday by retaining her super-giant slalom title.
Kostner clocked one minute 23.50 seconds down the Kandahar-Banchetta piste to beat Germany's Olympic downhill and former world super-G champion Katja Seizinger by 0.08 seconds.
Germany's Hilde Gerg was third in 1:23.64.
It was Italy's third gold in three women's races and the host nation moved to the top of the medals table.

Kostner, who won gold last year in the southern Spanish resort of Sierra Nevada, also became the second Italian woman in as many races to retain a world title after Compagnoni won the slalom last week and retained her giant title on Sunday.
The 21-year-old Kostner also has a very real chance of winning again in Saturday's downhill. She has won three World Cup downhills in her career to just one super-G.
Before 1996, when Italy won a total of four golds, no Italian woman had won a recognised world championship race.
Remarkably, Kostner made up 0.40 seconds in the final stages after a slow start when she trailed Seizinger's time.
Sweden's Pernilla Wiberg, winner of two World Cup super-Gs this season, was well down the field.
She finished in 1:24.47 after losing time coming off the final jump and skiing wide of the racing line earlier.
"I made a big mistake on one of the last turns," the Swede said. "I really blew it."
